data.title: Allow for sublime style "Paste and Indent"
data.body:
I can't seem to find any packages or settings in atom that can replicate Sublime's "Paste and Indent" behavior. What I want atom to do is to truncate the whitespace ahead of the content on the line and paste where my cursor is at. In both cases I triple click each line to select the entire contents.

Here are two gifs showing the difference, and in the atom gif I have the settings `autoIndentOnPaste: false` and `normalizeIndentOnPaste: false`
# Atom

![alt tag](http://i.imgur.com/6X33KhA.gif)
# Sublime (Paste and Indent)

![alt tag](http://i.imgur.com/t1Dg82a.gif)

Is there a way to get the same kind of behavior in Atom?

data.title: Cannot scroll through tree view when dragging a file
data.body:
When dragging a file to move it in the tree view, trying to scroll up or down while dragging the file will first drop the file wherever your cursor currently is, then scroll. The file should remain in a dragging state until the left click is released.

Atom version: 1.4.1
OS: Windows 10 Pro x64

data.title: Can't drag tab between two 'splits' when using the Awesome window manager
data.body:
I have one window with a vertical split. I'm trying to drag one tab from one side to the other, the tab doesn't ever get moved to the other side. 

This seems to only happen when using '[awesome](http://awesome.naquadah.org/)'. I have tried this with openbox on the the same machine without issue. 

I'm using version 1.4.0

data.title: Add TextEditor::{onWill,onDid}MutateSelectedText
data.body:
Before this PR, we could catch edits to the buffer (or the editor) only on a per-change basis (e.g. `onDidChange` or `onDidInsertText`), thus preventing packages to schedule work at the beginning or at the end of a multi-cursor change.

This PR adds `onWillMutateSelectedText` and `onDidMutateSelectedText` on `TextEditor`, which will respectively trigger at the beginning and at the end of a `mutateSelectedText` operation.

@nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld @kuychaco: although similar, these new APIs serve a different purpose than the `TextBuffer.prototype.setTextsInBufferRanges` API (and the possible associated events) we have talked about, as they're meant to catch only user-triggered changes to the editor and they're much higher level, as they won't provide information about the changes (adding such information would indeed be tricky, as selections could do an arbitrary number of changes to the underlying buffer, and it would require a much more invasive refactoring).

On the other hand, adding these is super cheap and provides an entry point for coarse-grained batching operations. What do you think? I am planning to use them in autocomplete-plus (a PR is on the way to that repo which will show how it'd work).

data.title: Saving files in a safer way
data.body:
We have found that Atom is overwriting file using `fs.writeFileSync()` in both `TextBuffer::saveAs` and writing a configuration file. Note that `fs.writeFileSync()` opens a file with `O_TRUNC` flag. Imagine that there is a system crash in between, all data may be gone, leaving a blank file in the file-system. Our automated tool found this potential crash unsafety. This is particularly important when there is no backup file -- even if no backup file means less guarantee (the backup file treatment is correct).

The correct way to save a file: (1) write contents to a backup file; (2) rename the backup to the original file. The key is that (2) is ensured to be atomic by modern file-system implementations (like ext4). It is optional to add a fdatasync() between (1) and (2) in Linux, though I am not quite sure of behaviors under Windows.

Here are some discussions FYI: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1812115/how-to-safely-write-to-a-file.

data.title: Indent is not kept when inserting multiple line breaks
data.body:
I noticed that when you make multiple break lines the indent is not kept in all the lines, only in the last one.

I'm using the version 1.4.1 for Windows. I ran the `--safe` mode but the terminal not shows anything and the inspector neither.

That's my `config.cson` file:

``` cson
"*":
  "atom-ternjs": {}
  core: {}
  editor:
    invisibles: {}
    preferredLineLength: 120
    showIndentGuide: true
    showInvisibles: true
    softWrap: true
    softWrapAtPreferredLineLength: true
    softWrapHangingIndent: 2
    tabLength: 4
    tabType: "soft"
  "exception-reporting":
    userId: "b35b1cd9-ec96-b463-d5a0-bc606c05fbf9"
  linter:
    errorPanelHeight: 180
  "markdown-preview":
    breakOnSingleNewline: true
    useGitHubStyle: true
  minimap:
    plugins:
      bookmarks: true
      "find-and-replace": true
      "highlight-selected": true
  tabs:
    tabScrolling: true
    usePreviewTabs: true
  welcome:
    showOnStartup: false
".md.text":
  editor:
    preferredLineLength: 120
```

data.title: Package author images are broken on Windows installs
data.body:
The author images for packages are often broken. I usually notice it in the update section, as shown below. This has been happening on both my work and home Windows machines (10 and 8.1, respectively). Sometimes they do display correctly, but it's very hit-or-miss. Not a terribly critical issue, but wanted to report it. The below image is from Atom 1.4.0 on Windows 10.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2487968/12626109/f09b34de-c504-11e5-9323-9abe78c44316.png)

data.title: Does Atom have "projects"?
data.body:
I'm looking into developing a plugin for Atom but I will need to have/store some project specific info (like credentials to connect to a server, and some other project specific settings).

ST has something similar and you can save this info in this "project file" (.sublime-project file). Here you can have/save custom values, list of files/folders added to the current project, etc...

Is there something like this available for Atom?

data.title: Periodically save state and store in indexedDB
data.body:
Fixes [atom/atom#4161](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/4161)
- [x] separate serialization from package deactivation
- [x] extract serialization logic from unloadEditorWindow
- [x] fix package manager tests
- [x] save state asynchronously on keydown and mousedown, write tests
- [x] get rid of AtomEnvironment state instance variable
- [x] fix AtomEnvironment tests
- [x] profile serialization time for various environment states
- [x] store state in IndexedDB
- [x] add command-line flag to clear indexedDB object store

data.title: Program freezes when on windows 10 in split view
data.body: I love using Atom for the core features and packages it comes with off the start but recently two project files that are both over 30 mb have been experiencing freezing up when dragging the program to the side and split viewing it with a web browser. Once I split view atom with chrome, i cannot click the code and change or highlight it at all. Because of this issue I am left using Sublime Text 3 or Brackets when Atom does this. Is there any news on when this issue may be fixed, because I have a samsung evo 840 sdd, i7, and 16 gb ddr3 so hardware should not be an issue.

data.title: Reagan concept
Samba shares and Atom
data.body:
Hello,

I have some problems with Atom and Samba shares. All samba shares that i used have their own Git repo. The first problem is that the package Git diff believes that all files are modified, but after changing the Git config (core.fileMode) works the package perfectly. But that's an option for me. The second problem is that Atom sometimes crashed with samba shares. It seems that Atom has difficulty waiting for a response from Samba. The last problem is that changing words in a samba share can damage files. The word had to be changed is replaced with nothing.

data.title: "Add Project Folder" doesn't open when no window present on OS X
data.body:
Steps to reproduce
1. Open Atom
2. If you have any windows open, close them without quitting the application
3. Go to menu File > Add Project Folder
4. Nothing happens
5. Create a new window from menu File > New Window
6. Go to menu File > Add Project Folder
7. Folder picker opens

More annoying than anything. I still can go Cmd + O and open folder I need.

data.title: Possible data loss when editing files on Samba shares, from OS X, in Atom 1.4
data.body:
A few days ago, I opened #10558: "Temp files are created on Samba shares that aren't deleted on close, can't be deleted manually, and are only deleted upon unmounting the share".

I'm seeing similar behavior _but with edited files as well_ - not just temp files.

I've only seen this once - but I've only performed 2 editing sessions in Atom 1.4 in which I edited files on a Samba share, so those aren't great odds.

As I said in #10558, I didn't see this issue in 1.3.x.  I edited lots and lots of files on Samba shares in 1.3.x and had no problems at all.

A little bit more about the setup:

OS X 10.10.5 running a Windows 7 SP1 VM in VMWare Fusion 7.  Some directories are shared from the Windows 7 VM using Windows file sharing.

Steps:
1.  Using Finder in OS X, mount a Samba share from the Windows VM.
2.  Open Atom.
3.  Open a file on the Samba share in Atom.
4.  Edit the file, save, edit, save, etc.
5.  Close the file in Atom.
6.  Open another file, edit, save, edit, save, etc.
7.  Close Atom.

At this point, everything seemed good.  Later, I attempted to edit the file opened in step 2 from within the Windows VM.  Reading the file worked, but it was locked for writing.

I dismounted the Samba share to see if that closed the handle.

It did close the handle.  _It also entirely deleted the file I had been editing_.

Now, there are several moving parts in the above scenario: Atom, OS X, Fusion, a Windows VM.  I can't guarantee that Atom is the part causing the data loss.  But I haven't seen files get locked like this, and only unlocked _and deleted_ when the share is unmounted (as in #10558, which is specifically about temp files) except in Atom >= 1.4.0.

~~Let me know if I should merge this issue with #10558.~~  I merged that issue with this one - see comments below.

EDIT: #10598 - "Samba shares and Atom" - which was closed as a dupe of this one - notes

> The last problem is that changing words in a samba share can damage files. The word had to be changed is replaced with nothing.

I'm not positive what that means, but it reminds me that I missed a step 8 above: In the Windows VM, rename the file opened in step 3.

Maybe it does mean what I think it means, which also would seem to match my experience:

if you edit a file on a Samba share in Atom, and then rename the same file via the OS that the Samba share resides on, then when the Samba share is dismounted the file is deleted completely.  Sometimes.  At least on OS X.

data.title: Document installation prerequisites in Readme
data.body:
Just Git for now.

Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10390
Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10388

data.title: Search doesn't work when same search term is entered
data.body:
I use the Quick Project switcher all the time.
If I search for say `myVariable` in Project A then switch to Project B and keep the search term the say, whether that's leaving that field alone or retyping it, nothing is searched.

I think it'd be a handy thing to have it _always_ research when I press search, maybe as a setting?

data.title: @ character in latin american keyboard does not work correctly

![before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16830249/12582861/ac08b4ec-c40d-11e5-9b3d-bd291781b05b.png)
![after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16830249/12582860/ac0109b8-c40d-11e5-98a8-17bcf1447276.png)

data.title: Unable to add keymap for sorting lines
data.body:
I added the following to my keymap:

```
'atom-text-editor':
  'f5': 'lines:sort'
```

But am still unable to sort with `f5`.

data.title: Unable to rename files with long names
data.body:
Given a filename of more than a handful of characters, I am not able to rename it, because I am not able to scroll horizontally to the end of the name.

Here's a screenshot. It shows the maximum length of highlighting or scroll movement that I can do.

![screen shot 2016-01-26 at 11 26 20](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8651/12578309/547dbdea-c420-11e5-867b-81580f9cb341.png)

**Atom version:** 1.4.0
**OS and version:** OS X El Capitan

**Installed packages:**
- wordcount
- git-plus
- tag (all disabled)

**Additional information:**
- Problem can be reproduced in safe mode: Yes
- Problem started happening recently, didn't happen in an older version of Atom: No
- Problem can be reliably reproduced, doesn't happen randomly: Yes
- Problem happens with all files and projects, not only some files or projects: Yes

data.title: Updating atom is ridiculous slow
data.body:
This is a great editor but poor implementation, Atom editor has a lot going for it and it also has a lot against it

1 ) its still not great at opening large files
2 ) crashes from time to time
3 ) updating is a chore
4 ) loading times are not great

Im updating from arch , I had atom editor installed before it got it's first stable version and I wasn't happy with the updating process , Rapid application development is all well and good, but when it takes 5 minutes  to update the program because of modules, it becomes a task not a process and I haven't time nor the patience to wait for the update everytime theres a new release or rev and there's a lot of them ... 

There has to be a better way of updating the modules in a faster or more convenient way !!! 

I thought after the stable version the updating process would be a lot faster , I was wrong as it's getting worse with more modules being adding eventually you will be left waiting for 10 minutes for this thing to upgrade thats ridiculous if the release's were kept back a little longer it wouldn't be so bad but the fact there's so many updates its painful and I've no time this, Uninstalling atom editor , Its the only program I actually wish there isn't an update for when I boot up my machine.
